children.name: now
children.definition: /naʊ/  at this moment or at this time:
examples: ▪ if we leave now we’ll be there before dark.
▪ it’s not raining now, but they said it might rain later.
▪ he used to coach high school basketball but now he’s a realtor.
from now onstarting from now
▪ students are to be in their seats by 8:00 from now on.
▪ from now on, the u.s. government will rely on a new method to measure economic growth.

children.name: currently
children.definition: /ˈkʌrəntliǁˈkɜːr-/  now - use this when you are describing what the situation is at this time:
examples: hiện tại, hiện nay
▪ the firm currently employs 113 people.
▪ currently, the most a senior nurse can earn is £16,000.
▪ ms. kelly is currently assisting another customer. may i help you?

children.name: at present
children.definition: /at the present time/ət ˈprezənt, ət ðə ˌprezənt ˈtaɪm/ formalif something istrueat present or at the present time, it is true now but you donotexpectit to bepermanent:
examples: hiện tại , hiện giờ
▪ the money available for public libraries will be less in future than at present.
▪ we do not envisage any changes in the tax structure at the present time.

children.name: right now
children.definition: /ˌraɪt ˈnaʊ/ spokenat this moment or at this time:
examples: ▪ i need a new car but right now i can’t afford one.
▪ she’s in amsterdam right now but she should be in paris by tomorrow night.

children.name: just now
children.definition: /ˌdʒʌst ˈnaʊ/  britishspokenat this exact moment - use this especially to say that youcannot do something immediately:
examples: ▪ sorry, i’m busy just now - can i call you later?

children.name: at the moment
children.definition: /presently/ət ðə ˈməʊmənt, ˈpresəntli/  now - use this especially to say that something is happening now but you donotexpectittocontinuefor a long time:
examples: hiện tại, hiện giờ
▪ i’m working in a restaurant at the moment.
▪ miss hellman is away from her desk at the moment - can i have her call you back?
▪ the official currency is the crown, presently about 30 to the dollar.

children.name: at this time
children.definition: /ət ˌðɪs ˈtaɪm/  american at this particular time:
examples: ở thời điểm này
▪ i have no further questions at this time, your honor.
▪ ‘do you have any health insurance?’ ‘not at this time.’
at this time of day/night/year etc
▪ what are you doing out at this time of night?
▪ gas prices always go up at this time of year.

children.name: now
children.definition: /naʊ/  use this when you are comparing the present situation with what happened in the past:
examples: bây giờ
▪ we used to be good friends but i don’t see very much of her now.
▪ julie has moved to a new school and she’s much happier now.

children.name: nowadays
children.definition: /these days/ˈnaʊədeɪz, ˈðiːz ˌdeɪz/  use this when you aredescribinghow lifeisdifferentnow from the way it was in the past. these days is more common in spoken english:
examples: ngày nay , thời nay
▪ it seems you’re not allowed to smoke anywhere nowadays.
▪ children can’t play in the street these days - the traffic’s too bad.
▪ nowadays, you hardly ever seen anyone wearing a tie to work.

children.name: today
children.definition: /təˈdeɪ/  at the present time, especially whencomparedwith the past:
examples: ngày nay , thời nay
▪ today, only a few of these beautiful animals survive.
▪ couples today are much more likely to marry in their 30s.
▪ the cost to install solar panels has dropped from $20 a watt in 1980 to as little as $5 today.

children.name: in this day and age
children.definition: /ɪn ˈðɪs deɪ ənd ˌeɪdʒ/  use this to show that you are surprised and shocked that something still happens now:
examples: trong thời đại ngày nay
▪ it’s not right, in this day and age, that people all over the world are still starving.
▪ it’s amazing that you can still find a house for under $100,000 in this day and age.

children.name: so far
children.definition: /ˌsəʊ ˈfɑːʳ/  until now - use this when you are talking about a situation thatwill continue or developafter this time:
examples: ▪ there haven’t been any problems so far.
▪ this is the hottest day we’ve had so far this summer.
▪ we’ve raised twelve thousand dollars so far, and we expect to reach our goal by the end of next week.

children.name: still
children.definition: /stɪl/  use this to say that a situation which started in the past continues to exist now, especially when this issurprising:
examples: vẫn
▪ he’s been studying french for five years, and still can’t speak the language.
▪ are you still going out with that guy you met at heather’s party?

children.name: yet
children.definition: /jet/  use this inquestionsornegativestatements, to talk or ask about things that you expected to happen before now:
examples: chưa
▪ has the new washing machine arrived yet?
▪ i haven’t been to the new exhibit yet, but i hope to this weekend.
▪ ‘have you finished your homework?’ ‘not yet.’

children.name: up to now/until now
children.definition: /ˌʌp tə ˈnaʊ, ənˌtɪl ˈnaʊ/  use this about a situation which has existed until now, but which has started to change or will change in the future:
examples: cho đến lúc này
▪ he hasn’t gotten much time off from work up to now, so he’s really looking forward to his vacation.
▪ until now, there has been no effective treatment for this disease.

children.name: up to the present day
children.definition: /until the present day/ˌʌp tə ðə ˌprezənt ˈdeɪ, ənˌtɪl ðə ˌprezənt ˈdeɪ/  from a time in the past until modern times:
examples: cho đến ngày nay
▪ these two companies have dominated the industry from the end of world war ii until the present day.
▪ the beauty of yosemite has inspired artists from bierstadt’s time right up to the present day.

children.name: happening now, but likely to change
for now
children.definition: /for the time being/fəʳ ˈnaʊ, fəʳ ðə ˌtaɪm ˈbiːɪŋ/  for a short time, but not permanently - use this about atemporaryarrangementorwayof dealingwith a situation:
examples: tạm thời, hiện tại
▪ leave the groceries there for now - i’ll put them away later.
▪ for the time being he can stay here, but i want that dog out of here by the end of the week.

children.name: for the moment
children.definition: /fəʳ ðə ˈməʊmənt/  especiallyspokenuse this to say that something is true or happening now, but may change soon:
examples: hiện tại
▪ for the moment the city seems quiet, but the fighting could start again at any time.
▪ ‘how’s your apartment?’ ‘it’s fine for the moment, but i’d rather live nearer town.’
▪ assuming for the moment that you did get the job, where would you live?

children.name: as of now
children.definition: /ˌæz əv ˈnaʊ/  american use this to say that something is true or happening now, but will probably change in the future:
examples: hiện tại thì
▪ as of now, there is no cure for multiple sclerosis.
▪ my plan, as of now, is to graduate in may then start looking for a job in the fall.

children.name: for the present
children.definition: /fəʳ ðə ˈprezənt/ formal:
examples: hiện tại
▪ it is assumed, for the present, that the meeting will go ahead.
▪ a reduction in interest rates seems highly unlikely for the present.

children.name: in the meanwhile
children.definition: /in the meantime/ɪn ðə ˈmiːnwaɪl, ɪn ðə ˈmiːntaɪm/  between now and some time in the future, for example until a situation changes:
examples: trong khi đó
▪ payday is not until next week, but if you need any money in the meanwhile, let me know.
▪ you probably won’t receive the contract until thursday but i can fax you a copy in the meantime.
meanwhile
▪ the flight will be announced soon. meanwhile, please remain seated.

children.name: when st does not happen now
no longer
children.definition: /nəʊ ˈlɒŋgəʳǁ-ˈlɔːŋ-/  use this to say that a situation that existed until recently does not exist now:
examples: ko nữa
▪ he no longer felt sure that he was right.
+ adj
▪ the bridge had collapsed, and it was no longer possible to cross the river.

children.name: not now
children.definition: /nɒt ˈnaʊ/  use this to say that something happened in the past, but it does not happen now:
examples: bây giờ thì không ( quá khứ thì có )
▪ when i was younger i spent hours lying out in the sun but not now.
▪ people used to respect teachers, but they don’t now.

children.name: not any more
children.definition: /ˌnɒt eni ˈmɔːʳ/  used when something has changed, especiallysuddenly:
examples: ko ... nữa
▪ alex doesn’t work here any more.
▪ do what you like. i don’t care any more!
▪ at one time doctors recommended red meat as part of a healthy diet but not any more.

children.name: existing, happening, or relating to now
current
children.definition: /ˈkʌrəntǁˈkɜːr-/  use this about asituationoractivitywhich is happening now, but which isnotexpectedtocontinuefor a long time:
examples: hiện tại, hiện hành, hiện nay
▪ in the current economic situation, switching careers may not be such a good idea.
▪ coca-cola’s current advertising campaign
current level/rate/price
▪ the aim is to reduce current pollution levels in the black sea.
▪ according to one economist, at the current growth rate, china will have the largest economy in the world by 2030.

children.name: present
children.definition: /ˈprezənt/  the presentsituationis the one that exists now; your present job, address etc is the one that you have now:
examples: hiện tại
▪ arnaud lived in los angeles before moving to his present home in new york.
▪ he warned that the present situation could get much worse.

children.name: existing
children.definition: /ɪgˈzɪstɪŋ/  use this aboutthingsorsituationsthat exist now, when you think they may be changed in the future:
examples: hiện tại
▪ the existing building is too small, and there are plans to replace it within the next five years.
▪ many people feel that the existing law discriminates against women.

children.name: today’s/of today
children.definition: /təˈdeɪz, əv təˈdeɪ/  use this aboutsocial,economic, orpoliticalconditions and attitudes that exist now, when you arecomparingthem with those that existed in the past:
examples: ngày nay, thời nay
▪ the first computers were extremely slow by today’s standards.
▪ the teenagers of today have a different attitude to sex.

children.name: modern-day/present-day
children.definition: /ˈmɒdn deɪǁˈmɑːdərn-, ˈprezənt deɪ/  a present-day situation, fact, idea etc is one that exists now rather than in the past:
examples: thời nay, ngày nay
▪ modern-day equipment has made mining much safer than it was.
▪ there is no modern-day racing driver who could be compared with fangio.
▪ prussia reached its zenith in 1795, encompassing most of northern germany and present-day poland.

children.name: modern
children.definition: /ˈmɒdnǁˈmɑːdərn/  belonging to the present time or most recent time and not to the past:
examples: hiện đại
▪ i don’t like modern architecture at all.
▪ the pyramids are a remarkable piece of engineering, even judged by modern standards.
▪ the most compelling work in the modern british theater is being created in the smaller and non-profit theaters.

children.name: contemporary
children.definition: /kənˈtempərəri, -pəriǁ-pəreri/  contemporary art, writing, thought, society etc is the type that exists, is accepted, or belongs to, the present time:
examples: đương thời
▪ contemporary indian cinema has its roots in folk culture.
▪ the declining importance of religion in contemporary societies

children.name: topical
children.definition: /ˈtɒpɪkəlǁˈtɑː-/  a story, subject, problem etc that is topical isinterestingbecause it deals with something that is important at the moment:
examples: thời sự
▪ it’s an old story but it has a topical message.
▪ in the 1970s, he recorded topical songs about watergate and the vietnam war.
▪ the editor thinks that if an article isn’t topical it isn’t worth publishing.

children.name: latter-day
children.definition: /ˈlætəʳ deɔ/  someone who exists now and is a very similar type of person as someone who existed in the past:
examples: thời hiện đại ( nhân vật trong quá khứ )
▪ romer portrayed himself as a latter-day robin hood who took money and gave it to the underprivileged.
